awd_titl_txt: CRCNS US-German Research Proposal: Neural Computations Underlying Mechanical -Flow Sensing in Zebrafish
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, the zebrafish has emerged as an important model organism as researchers have become able to obtain detailed information about the connectivity and activity of its brain.  The laboratory of the Principal Investigator recently presented work that makes use of this wealth of available information to better understand zebrafish behavior at the level of specific neural circuitry. To that end, a realistic network model, composed of experimental verified functional cell types, was developed that accurately models the fish's tendency to swim in a particular direction in response to a moving visual stimulus. The purpose of this collaboration project is to develop a similar theoretical circuit model for mechanosensory-based rheotaxis, a more sophisticated behavior that also is displayed readily by larval zebrafish. The project combines experimental and computational approaches, and constitutes a significant step towards establishing the larval zebrafish as a vertebrate model where whole-brain imaging can be combined with whole-brain circuit modelling in order to generate a unified theoretical basis for the holistic study of neural circuits.  The project also provides undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds opportunities to receive hands-on laboratory experiences.

As a first step towards the scientific goal of the project, the investigators demonstrated that larval zebrafish can perform efficient rheotaxis in complete darkness and in the absence of any other direct cues from the external reference frame.  Furthermore, the investigators showed that this behavior requires the presence of a flow velocity gradient, and presented behavioral data that support a novel algorithm that fish use to efficiently navigate laminar flow:  detailed behavioral analysis shows that fish use the hair-cells of their lateral line to measure (1) the curl of the local velocity vector field to detect the presence of flow, and (2) the temporal change in curl magnitude following swim bouts to deduce flow direction. As such, a precise and predictive algorithm is presented, whose quantitative description allows to examine its neural implementation, and eventually to generate a realistic and testable circuit model of all brain areas involved in executing this computation. The complementary expertise of the researchers of the two participating laboratories allows testing, verification, and refinement of this model-circuit based on an iterative combination of whole-brain imaging, genetic perturbations and quantitative modeling. A companion project is being funded by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research, Germany (BMBF).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The details of this circuit model and how it was derived in the context of the project is outlined in the following and summarized in the embedded Figure. Panel A depicts suggested neuronal ensembles that likely implement the algorithmic recipe underlying rheotaxis, whose structure and specific connectivity emerged as a result of the behavioral experiments conducted in the context of the award. The dissection of the circuitry underlying this complex behavior is particularly appealing, since it requires the sequential execution of several computations that generalize broadly to a large variety of behaviors in almost all animal species. The first of these computations is spatial integration, which in this case requires the computation of curl, which is calculated by obtaining a “line integral” through summing over all the polarized hair cell receptors along the fish’s lateral line. Specifically, the fish needs to sum activity from all forward-flow encoding hair cell signals (i.e. tuned to tail-to-head flow, always shown in purple) from one side, relay the information through the Medial Octavolateralis Nucleus (MON) to the Torus Semicircularis (TS) where the activity will be combined with information from backward-flow encoding hair cells (tuned to head-to-tail, shown in green) from the other side. The predicted response properties (=regressors) of putative curl detector neurons (CDN), which are expected to be located in the TS, are shown in dark blue for a variety of bilaterally asymmetric flow stimuli (Figure B). The need to compare flow before and after a swim bout implies further that the measurement of curl is stored as a form of working memory in interconnected inhibitory neurons, also located in the TS (iTSN, regressor shown in light blue). This activity needs to last beyond the execution of the next swim bout, and it is currently still unclear how exactly such persistent activity patterns could be implemented. One possibility is that recurrent excitatory connections between these neurons generate these long time constants, a hypothesis that is testable also by dense connectomics reconstructions. This implementation may be evident only at the population rather than the single neuron level, which generates the need to apply population decoding strategies to uncover the populations responsible for the maintenance of the measurement.

A final necessary computation for the correct behavioral execution is the comparison and subtraction of two sequentially measured curl values that are separated by a swim bout. We predict that these differential curl detector neurons (dCDN), exist in two flavors, one for clockwise (cw-dCDN) and one for counterclockwise curl (ccw-dCDN), and that they respond only to an increase in sequentially measured curl values. We predict that the cw-dCDN will induce a large angle turn in the right when activated and that the ccw-dCDN will induce left directed turns (dCDN, regressor shown in orange).

Since a swim bout occurs between the two consecutive curl measurements, a very strong reafferent hair cell stimulation is expected to occur at this moment, and a process needs to be in place, analogous to saccadic suppression, that either corrects for, or cancels out, such a strong and uninformative perturbation. In the context of this project we have also shown that all hair cells of the neuromast are strongly inhibited by cholinergic efferent activity from the Octavolateralis Efferent Nucleus (OEN) during a swim, which effectively cancels out these interference signals. Figure B illustrates that all of these regressors make highly specific predictions about the location and response properties of the involved neurons, which makes it straightforward to design the experimental protocols necessary to confirm or reject the validity of our hypothesized circuits, and to convert them into realistic models
